text: basic example shows solve common problem: special using README.Rmd instead just README.md? can include R chunks like : ’ll still need render README.Rmd regularly, keep README.md --date. devtools::build_readme() handy . also use GitHub Actions re-render README.Rmd every time push. example workflow can found : https://github.com/r-lib/actions/tree/v1/examples. can also embed plots, example:  case, don’t forget commit push resulting figure files, display GitHub CRAN.

what: Two-sample win ratio (net benefit) analysis — wrtest
title: Two-sample win ratio (net benefit) analysis — wrtest
text: Estimate make inference win ratio (net benefit) comparing treatment control group.

title: Two-sample win ratio (net benefit) analysis — wrtest
Two-sample win ratio (net benefit) analysis — wrtest
text: Y1 \(K\)-variate response data \(n_1\) subjects treatment (\(n_1\times K\) matrix). Y0 \(K\)-variate response data \(n_0\) subjects control (\(n_0\times K\) matrix). fun User-specified win function pairwise comparison. takes two arguments \(y_1\) \(y_0\) (\(p\)-dimensional) returns 1 \(y_1\) wins, -1 \(y_0\) wins, 0 tied. default wprod based product order multivariate ordinal data.

title: Two-sample win ratio (net benefit) analysis — wrtest
text: object class wrtest following components: theta bivariate vector win/loss fractions LWR. lgwr, lgwr_se, lgwr_pval Log-win ratio estimate, standard error, p-value. nb, nb_se, nb_pval Net benefit estimate (theta[1]-theta[2]), standard error, p-value.

title: Two-sample win ratio (net benefit) analysis — wrtest
text: Mao, L. (2024). Win ratio partially ordered data. Statistica Sinica, revision. Buyse, M. (2010).  Generalized pairwise  comparisons prioritized outcomes two‐sample problem.  Statistics Medicine, 29, 3245-3257.

title: Two-sample win ratio (net benefit) analysis — wrtest
code: head(liver) #>   R1-NASH R2-NASH Sex    AF Steatosis  SSF2  LSN #> 1       3       2   M FALSE        30  0.21 2.33 #> 2       1       1   F FALSE         5  0.38 2.86 #> 3       4       2   M FALSE        70  0.58 3.65 #> 4       4       4   F  TRUE        30 -0.08 2.73 #> 5       4       3   M  TRUE        70 -0.04 2.53 #> 6       3       3   M FALSE        10  0.02 2.88 ### data example ## compare bivariate fibrosis ratings between fibrosis ## stages >= 3 and < 3

what: A dataset from a non-alcoholic fatty liver disease — liver
title: A dataset from a non-alcoholic fatty liver disease — liver
text: total 186 patients non-alcoholic fatty liver disease recruited University Wisconsin Hospitals 2017. patients underwent computed tomography scan liver presence non-alcoholic steato-hepatitis, severe form non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. image subsequently assessed two radiologists using scale 1 5, higher values indicating greater likelihood disease.

title: A dataset from a non-alcoholic fatty liver disease — liver
A dataset from a non-alcoholic fatty liver disease — liver
text: data frame 186 rows (one per patient) 7 variables: R1-NASH, R2-NASH Unique patient ID. Sex M: male; F: female. AF Advanced fibrosis (TRUE FALSE). Steatosis Percent steatosis. SSF2 Liver mean gray level intensity. LSN Liver surface nodularity.

title: A dataset from a non-alcoholic fatty liver disease — liver
text: Mao, L. (2024). Win ratio partially ordered data. Statistica Sinica, revision.

what: poset: Analysis of Partially Ordered Data — poset-package
title: poset: Analysis of Partially Ordered Data — poset-package
text: Win ratio approach partially ordered data, multivariate ordinal responses product (consensus) prioritized order. Two-sample tests multiplicative regression models implemented (Mao, 2024).

title: Print results from wrtest — print.wrtest
text: Print results two-sample win ratio (net benefit) analysis, include point estimates, 95% confidence intervals, p-values.

title: Print results from wrtest — print.wrtest
Print results from wrtest — print.wrtest
text: x object returned wrtest. ... arguments passed methods

title: Print results from wrtest — print.wrtest
text: return value, called side effects.

what: The product-order win function for multivariate ordinal data — wprod
title: The product-order win function for multivariate ordinal data — wprod
text: commonly used rule compare    multivariate ordinal data wrtest. winner components    greater equal loser, strictly    least one component.

title: The product-order win function for multivariate ordinal data — wprod
The product-order win function for multivariate ordinal data — wprod
text: y1 \(K\)-dimensional vector \(y_1\). y2 \(K\)-dimensional vector  \(y_2\).

title: The product-order win function for multivariate ordinal data — wprod
text: integer \({1, 0, -1}\): 1 \(y_1 \ge y_2\) component-wise, strict inequality least                  one component. -1 \(y_0 \ge y_2\) component-wise, strict inequality least                  one component. 0 Otherwise.

what: Multiplicative win ratio (MWR) regression analysis — wreg
title: Multiplicative win ratio (MWR) regression analysis — wreg
text: Fit multiplicative win ratio (MWR) regression model partially ordered outcome covariates

title: Multiplicative win ratio (MWR) regression analysis — wreg
code: wreg(Y, Z, wf = NULL, sfun = NULL, ep = 1e-06)

title: Multiplicative win ratio (MWR) regression analysis — wreg
text: Y \(n\times K\) matrix containing \(n\) observations \(K\)-dimensional outcome variable (whose components must variable type). Z \(n\times p\) design matrix covariates. wf User-specified win function pairwise comparison. takes two arguments \(y_1\) \(y_0\) (\(K\)-dimensional) returns 1 \(y_1\) wins, -1 \(y_0\) wins, 0 tied. default wprod based product order multivariate ordinal data. sfun score function used pseudo-efficient estimation (can bypassed). ep Convergence criterion Newton-Raphson algorithm. default 1e-6.

title: Multiplicative win ratio (MWR) regression analysis — wreg
text: object class wreg following components: beta vector estimated regression coefficients. Sigma Estimated covariance matrix beta l Number Newton-Raphson iterations. beta_nv Naive (non-pseudo-efficient) estimates beta. se_nv Estimated standard errors beta_nv. n Sample size \(n\) input data. Nwl Number comparable pairs (winner loser) \(n(n+1)/2\) possible ones.

title: Multiplicative win ratio (MWR) regression analysis — wreg
text: Mao, L. (2024). Win ratio partially ordered data. Statistica Sinica, revision.

title: Multiplicative win ratio (MWR) regression analysis — wreg
